item.title: User Management
item.description:
User Account

/etc/passwd

Linux uses the /etc/passwd file to store user account information. Because many service processes need to read user account information, you can see that the file’s permissions are all readable.

User/Group Relationship

Primary Group

When a user is created, a group with the same name is also created, which is the primary group.

item.title: File Permission
item.description:
Composition Structure

The first character indicates the file type:

  • -：File, such as text files, binary files, etc.
  • d：Directory.
  • l：Symbolic link, Symbolic link (Soft link).
  • b：Block device, such as hard disk, CD-ROM, etc.
  • c：Character device, such as terminal device, keyboard, etc.
  • p：Pipe, inter-process communication.
  • s：Socket, network communication, data exchange between processes.

item.title: Access Control List
item.description:
ACL

Access Control List (ACL) is a more flexible and fine-grained permission management mechanism, used to define and control the access permissions of file system objects. Compared to traditional file permission systems, ACL provides more detailed permission control, allowing you to set specific permissions for different users and user groups, no longer limited to the traditional three roles (Owner, Group, Others).
